articles.headline: Aid Is Getting to Puerto Rico. Distributing It Remains a Challenge.
articles.snippet: Two weeks after Hurricane Maria, many are still receiving only meager portions and delivery is being hampered by bureaucracy and tough logistics.
articles.abstract: Two weeks after Hurricane Maria, many are still receiving only meager portions and delivery is being hampered by bureaucracy and tough logistics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS MARÍAS, P.R. — Inside a dark school sheltering families left homeless by landslides and hurricane winds, bottled water was getting so scarce on Monday that relief workers parceled out one small plastic cup to go with each person’s dinner of hot dogs, rice and beans and syrupy apricots.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Frances Robles and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: With Affordable Care Act’s Future Cloudy, Costs for Many Seem Sure to Soar
articles.snippet: Some insurers have been granted double-digit rate increases for 2018 amid questions about the stability of the individual market.
articles.abstract: Some insurers have been granted double-digit rate increases for 2018 amid questions about the stability of the individual market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health insurers are aggressively increasing prices next year for individual policies sold under the federal health care law, with some raising premiums by more than 50 percent.

articles.headline: Uber’s Board Approves Changes to Reshape Company’s Power Balance
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing service’s board voted for corporate governance changes and a potential stock sale to the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing service’s board voted for corporate governance changes and a potential stock sale to the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s board of directors voted on Tuesday for governance changes that will reshape the balance of power at the ride-hailing service, paving the way for a stock sale to the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank and for the company to go public by 2019.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: For Music Fans Drawn to Las Vegas, a Retreat Became a Trap
articles.snippet: Thousands of people who had come from far away suddenly found themselves under fire.
articles.abstract: Thousands of people who had come from far away suddenly found themselves under fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: The weekend was perfect for an escape. It was Las Vegas, the poster city for getting away, and a dazzling lineup of entertainment beckoned, a three-day country music festival known as Route 91.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Amy Harmon

articles.headline: Meticulous Planning by Las Vegas Gunman Before He Opened Fire
articles.snippet: New details emerged about how Stephen Paddock managed to kill 58 people and himself, and investigators said they hoped to learn more from his girlfriend.
articles.abstract: New details emerged about how Stephen Paddock managed to kill 58 people and himself, and investigators said they hoped to learn more from his girlfriend.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Before he mowed down concertgoers from a perch high in a hotel tower, Stephen C. Paddock created a ring of surveillance around him, with video cameras in his suite and in the hallway, law enforcement officials said on Tuesday. But investigators were still at a loss to offer a motive for the massacre.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina, Richard Pérez-Peña and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Where Driverless Cars Brake for Golf Carts
articles.snippet: The start-up Voyage is testing its self-driving taxi service in a gated community of about 4,000 residents where the average age is 76.
articles.abstract: The start-up Voyage is testing its self-driving taxi service in a gated community of about 4,000 residents where the average age is 76.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Molly Jackson, an 82-year-old retired nurse, was sitting in the back seat of a self-driving taxi when the vehicle jerked to a halt at a crossing as its computer vision spotted an approaching golf cart.

articles.headline: E.U., Citing Amazon and Apple, Tells Nations to Collect Tax
articles.snippet: The European Commission said it would take Ireland to court for not clawing back billions from Apple, and ordered Luxembourg to recover around $293 million from Amazon.
articles.abstract: The European Commission said it would take Ireland to court for not clawing back billions from Apple, and ordered Luxembourg to recover around $293 million from Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European competition regulators on Wednesday mounted a push against tax avoidance by Silicon Valley giants, announcing plans to take Ireland to court for failing to collect back taxes from Apple and ordering Luxembourg to claim unpaid taxes from Amazon.

articles.headline: Tillerson’s News Conference Only Highlights Strains With Trump
articles.snippet: The secretary of state had hoped to douse questions about how long he will stay, but instead further fueled a debate about his future.
articles.abstract: The secretary of state had hoped to douse questions about how long he will stay, but instead further fueled a debate about his future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long-simmering tension within President Trump’s national security team spilled into public view on Wednesday as Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson took the extraordinary step of calling a news conference to affirm his support for Mr. Trump, despite what associates describe as his deep frustration with the president and talk of resignation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush
